tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
A psalm of Asaph.
"This is for the director of music to use in worship;"
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:008:001|8:1]].
"This is a psalm that Asaph wrote"
The abstract noun "strength" can be stated as "strong." AT: "God who causes us to be strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "Jacob" represents all of his descendants. AT: "the God of Israel, the nation of Jacob's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: play the tambourine, the pleasant lyre with the harp
tn.text: These are musical instruments.
a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This is the beginning of the lunar month.

tn.ref: the day of the full moon
tn.text: This is the middle of the lunar month.
"and on the days when our feasts begin"
Here "it" refers to the feast day.

tn.ref: a decree given by the God of Jacob
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the God of Jacob decreed it" or "the God of Jacob commanded it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "Jacob" represents all of his descendants. AT: "the God of Israel, the nation of Jacob's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"gave it as a law"
Here "Joseph" represents all of the Israelites. AT: "to the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: when he went against the land of Egypt
tn.text: This refers to the historical events in Egypt when the people of Israel were enslaved and God rescued them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "land" represents the people. AT: "the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here God begins speaking.

tn.ref: removed the burden from his shoulder
tn.text: Here "the burden from his shoulder" represents the forced labor the Israelites had to do as slaves in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: his hands were freed from holding the basket
tn.text: Here "holding the basket" represents the forced labor the Israelites had to do as slaves in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"In your great suffering"

tn.ref: I answered you from a dark thundercloud
tn.text: When God came to the Israelites, he hid the fullness of his presence and glory in a dark and threatening cloud. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I tested you at the waters of Meribah
tn.text: God tested the children of Israel to see if they would trust him to supply water in the desert of Meribah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Yahweh reminds the people what he said while they were in the desert.
"because I am giving you a warning"
Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "Israelites" or "people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]]).

tn.ref: if you would only listen to me!
tn.text: "how I wish you would listen to me" or "but you must start listening to me!"

tn.ref: Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it
tn.text: God taking care of all the needs of the people is spoken of as if he were a mother bird feeding her baby birds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Now Yahweh tells what actually happened after he warned the people.
Here "words" represents what God said. AT: "to what I said" or "to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: So I gave them over to their own stubborn way
tn.text: God allowing the people to remain stubborn is spoken of as if God were giving them over to an enemy to let the enemy harm them. AT: "Therefore, I let them be stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: oh, that my people would walk in my paths
tn.text: God wanting the people to obey him is spoken of as if he wanted the people to walk on his paths or roads. AT: "I wish that they would obey my laws" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "hand" represents Yahweh's power. AT: "I would destroy" or "I would defeat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "who hate me ... before me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"bow down in fear" or "fall down in fear"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I would humiliate them forever" or "I will punish them forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I would feed Israel with the finest wheat
tn.text: God causing the best wheat to grow in Israel is spoken of as if he would literally feed the wheat to the people. AT: "I would allow the Israelites to eat the finest wheat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Both "Israel" and "you" refer to the Israelites.
This refers to wild honey. Bees would build hives in the holes in rocks and make the honey there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
